com.twitter.elephantbird.util

Class TaskHeartbeatThread

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.twitter.elephantbird.util.TaskHeartbeatThread

  • public class TaskHeartbeatThread
extends Object
    Keeps a task alive during any slow operations
    Author:
    Alex Levenson

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      TaskHeartbeatThread(org.apache.hadoop.util.Progressable context, long periodMillis)
      Creates a new thread to keep a task alive Does not start the thread until you call start()
      TaskHeartbeatThread(org.apache.hadoop.mapreduce.TaskAttemptContext context)
      Same as #TaskHeartbeatThread(TaskAttemptContext, long) but with a default period of 1 minute

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      protected void progress()
      This will be called once every periodMillis.
      void start()
      Keep the task alive until stop() is called
      void stop()
      Stop keeping the task alive, make sure to call this when your slow operation is finished.

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

    • Constructor Detail

      • TaskHeartbeatThread

        public TaskHeartbeatThread(org.apache.hadoop.util.Progressable context,
                   long periodMillis)
        Creates a new thread to keep a task alive Does not start the thread until you call start()
        Parameters:
        context - the task attempt context, used to send progress signals to the task
        periodMillis - how often to wake up and send a progress signal in milliseconds

      • TaskHeartbeatThread

        public TaskHeartbeatThread(org.apache.hadoop.mapreduce.TaskAttemptContext context)
        Same as #TaskHeartbeatThread(TaskAttemptContext, long) but with a default period of 1 minute

    • Method Detail

      • start

        public void start()
        Keep the task alive until stop() is called

      • stop

        public void stop()
        Stop keeping the task alive, make sure to call this when your slow operation is finished. It's a good idea to wrap your slow code with a try { ... } finally {heartBeat.stop()}} to ensure that the heartBeat is stopped. If the heartBeat remains alive failed jobs can remain 'running' indefinitely.

      • progress

        protected void progress()
        This will be called once every periodMillis. Override to report progress of the slow close() method
